Definition: Cancer of myeloid blood cells, rapid growth of abnormal white blood cells
Etiology: Somatic genetic alterations in hematopoietic progenitor cells
Risk_Factors: Radiation exposure, Chemical exposure (benzene), Genetic disorders (Down syndrome), Family history, Advanced age
Pathophysiology: Altered mechanisms of self-renewal, proliferation, and differentiation
Symptoms: Fatigue, Frequent infections, Easy bruising/bleeding, Weight loss, Night sweats, Bone pain
Diagnostic_Methods: CBC with differential, Peripheral blood smear, Bone marrow biopsy, Immunophenotyping, Cytogenetic analysis, Molecular testing (FLT3, NPM1, CEBPA mutations)
Treatment_Protocols: Induction: 7+3 regimen (cytarabine + anthracycline), Consolidation: High-dose cytarabine or stem cell transplantation

Definition: Cancer where bone marrow makes too many lymphocytes
Risk_Factors: Family history, Advanced age, Environmental factors
Pathophysiology: Clonal expansion of mature B lymphocytes expressing CD5 and CD23
Symptoms: Fatigue, Frequent infections, Easy bruising/bleeding, Weight loss, Night sweats, Enlarged lymph nodes
Diagnostic_Methods: CBC with differential, Peripheral blood smear, Bone marrow biopsy, Immunophenotyping, FISH for genetic abnormalities
Treatment_Protocols: Watch and wait (asymptomatic), Chemoimmunotherapy (FCR), Targeted therapies (Ibrutinib, Venetoclax)

Definition: Decrease in total body iron
Risk_Factors: Menstruation, Gastrointestinal bleeding, Vegetarian diet, Pregnancy
Pathophysiology: Decreased iron leads to reduced hemoglobin synthesis, microcytic hypochromic RBCs
Symptoms: Fatigue, Shortness of breath, Pale skin, Dizziness, Chest pain (severe cases)
Diagnostic_Methods: CBC, Peripheral blood smear, Iron studies (serum iron, ferritin, TIBC)
Treatment_Protocols: Oral iron supplementation, Intravenous iron (severe cases), Treat underlying cause

Definition: Caused by impaired DNA synthesis
Risk_Factors: Strict vegan diet, Alcoholism, Certain medications, Pernicious anemia
Pathophysiology: Impaired DNA synthesis leads to asynchronous maturation of nucleus and cytoplasm, large immature RBCs
Symptoms: Fatigue, Shortness of breath, Pale skin, Dizziness, Cognitive impairment (B12 deficiency)
Diagnostic_Methods: CBC, Peripheral blood smear, Vitamin B12 and folate levels, Schilling test (for B12 deficiency)
Treatment_Protocols: Vitamin B12 injections, Folic acid supplementation

Definition: Cancer of lymph system, characterized by Reed-Sternberg cells
Etiology: Unknown, possibly related to Epstein-Barr virus
Risk_Factors: Immunosuppression, EBV infection, Family history
Pathophysiology: Orderly spread of disease from one lymph node group to another
Symptoms: Painless enlarged lymph nodes, B symptoms (fever, night sweats, weight loss), Fatigue, Itching
Diagnostic_Methods: Lymph node biopsy, Immunohistochemistry, PET-CT, Bone marrow biopsy
Treatment_Protocols: Early-stage: ABVD + radiation, Advanced-stage: ABVD or BEACOPP

Definition: Diverse group of lymphoid neoplasms
Risk_Factors: Immunosuppression, HIV infection, Certain infections, Autoimmune diseases, Chemical exposure
Pathophysiology: Varies by subtype, generally involves uncontrolled growth of lymphocytes
Symptoms: Painless enlarged lymph nodes, B symptoms, Fatigue, Splenomegaly or hepatomegaly
Diagnostic_Methods: Lymph node biopsy, Immunohistochemistry, Flow cytometry, Cytogenetic studies, PET-CT
Treatment_Protocols: Varies by subtype, Often includes R-CHOP chemotherapy, Radiation therapy, Stem cell transplant for relapsed/refractory cases

Definition: Characterized by t(15;17) translocation and production of PML-RARα fusion protein
Risk_Factors: Unknown
Pathophysiology: PML-RARα fusion protein blocks differentiation of promyelocytes
Symptoms: Severe bleeding tendency, Petechiae, Ecchymoses, Gingival bleeding, Fatigue
Diagnostic_Methods: CBC, Peripheral blood smear (hypergranular promyelocytes with Auer rods), Molecular testing for PML-RARA
Treatment_Protocols: ATRA + Arsenic Trioxide, Aggressive supportive care

Definition: Autoimmune disorder causing low platelet count
Risk_Factors: Unknown, sometimes follows viral infection
Pathophysiology: Accelerated platelet destruction by reticuloendothelial system
Symptoms: Petechiae, Easy bruising, Prolonged bleeding from cuts, Epistaxis, Gingival bleeding
Diagnostic_Methods: CBC, Peripheral blood smear, Bone marrow biopsy (in selected cases)
Treatment_Protocols: Corticosteroids, Thrombopoietin receptor agonists, Rituximab, Splenectomy (refractory cases)

Definition: Complication of heparin therapy causing low platelets and increased thrombosis risk
Risk_Factors: Heparin therapy (more common with unfractionated heparin)
Pathophysiology: Antibody-mediated platelet activation and clearance, paradoxical increase in thrombosis risk
Symptoms: Thrombocytopenia, Venous or arterial thrombosis
Diagnostic_Methods: 4T score, HIT antibody test (ELISA), Serotonin release assay
Treatment_Protocols: Discontinue all heparin, Start non-heparin anticoagulant (e.g., argatroban)

Treatment_Protocols: Discontinue all heparin, Start non-heparin anticoagulant (e.g., argatroban)

Definition: X-linked recessive bleeding disorder due to factor VIII deficiency
Etiology: Mutations in F8 gene on X chromosome
Risk_Factors: Family history, Male gender
Pathophysiology: Insufficient factor VIII leads to impaired clot formation
Symptoms: Easy bruising, Prolonged bleeding from cuts, Hemarthrosis, Intramuscular hematomas
Diagnostic_Methods: Factor VIII activity assay, PT/aPTT, Genetic testing
Treatment_Protocols: Factor VIII replacement therapy, Prophylaxis in severe cases, Desmopressin in mild cases

Definition: X-linked recessive bleeding disorder due to factor IX deficiency
Etiology: Mutations in F9 gene on X chromosome
Risk_Factors: Family history, Male gender
Pathophysiology: Insufficient factor IX leads to impaired clot formation
Symptoms: Easy bruising, Prolonged bleeding from cuts, Hemarthrosis, Intramuscular hematomas
Diagnostic_Methods: Factor IX activity assay, PT/aPTT, Genetic testing
Treatment_Protocols: Factor IX replacement therapy, Prophylaxis in severe cases

Definition: Myeloproliferative neoplasm with increased red blood cell production
Risk_Factors: Advanced age, Exposure to ionizing radiation
Pathophysiology: Uncontrolled proliferation of erythroid progenitors
Symptoms: Headache, Dizziness, Pruritus, Erythromelalgia, Thrombosis
Diagnostic_Methods: CBC, JAK2 mutation analysis, Bone marrow biopsy
Treatment_Protocols: Phlebotomy, Low-dose aspirin, Hydroxyurea (high-risk patients)

Definition: Inherited hemoglobin disorder with reduced or absent beta-globin chain production
Risk_Factors: Family history, Ethnic background (Mediterranean, Middle Eastern, Asian)
Pathophysiology: Imbalance in alpha/beta globin chain ratio leads to ineffective erythropoiesis
Symptoms: Anemia, Fatigue, Jaundice, Splenomegaly, Growth retardation (severe cases)
Diagnostic_Methods: CBC, Hemoglobin electrophoresis, Genetic testing
Treatment_Protocols: Regular blood transfusions, Iron chelation therapy, Stem cell transplantation (severe cases)

Definition: Inherited hemoglobin disorder with abnormal hemoglobin S
Risk_Factors: Family history, African ancestry
Pathophysiology: Abnormal hemoglobin S polymerizes under low oxygen conditions, causing RBC sickling
Symptoms: Pain crises, Anemia, Fatigue, Increased infections, Stroke risk
Diagnostic_Methods: CBC, Hemoglobin electrophoresis, Genetic testing
Treatment_Protocols: Hydroxyurea, Pain management, Prophylactic antibiotics, Blood transfusions

Definition: Cancer of plasma cells
Risk_Factors: Advanced age, Male gender, African American race, Radiation exposure, Family history
Pathophysiology: Malignant plasma cells produce abnormal antibodies and suppress normal antibody production
Symptoms: Bone pain, Fatigue, Anemia, Hypercalcemia, Renal insufficiency
Diagnostic_Methods: Serum/urine protein electrophoresis, Bone marrow biopsy, Imaging studies (X-ray, MRI, PET-CT)
Treatment_Protocols: Chemotherapy, Targeted therapy, Immunomodulators, Stem cell transplantation

Definition: Inherited bleeding disorder due to deficient or defective von Willebrand factor
Risk_Factors: Family history
Pathophysiology: Reduced or dysfunctional von Willebrand factor impairs platelet adhesion and factor VIII stability
Symptoms: Easy bruising, Mucosal bleeding, Menorrhagia, Prolonged bleeding after surgery
Diagnostic_Methods: VWF antigen assay, VWF activity assay, Factor VIII activity, Genetic testing
Treatment_Protocols: Desmopressin (DDAVP), VWF replacement therapy, Antifibrinolytics

Definition: Bone marrow failure syndrome with pancytopenia
Etiology: Idiopathic (most cases), Autoimmune, Radiation, Chemicals, Viruses
Risk_Factors: Exposure to toxins, Certain medications, Viral infections
Pathophysiology: Immune-mediated destruction of hematopoietic stem cells
Symptoms: Fatigue, Pallor, Frequent infections, Easy bruising/bleeding
Diagnostic_Methods: CBC, Peripheral blood smear, Bone marrow biopsy, Genetic testing (to rule out inherited forms)
Treatment_Protocols: Immunosuppressive therapy, Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation, Supportive care (transfusions)

Definition: Myeloproliferative neoplasm with increased platelet production
Risk_Factors: Advanced age, Female gender
Pathophysiology: Uncontrolled proliferation of megakaryocytes leading to excessive platelet production
Symptoms: Often asymptomatic, Headache, Visual disturbances, Erythromelalgia, Thrombosis risk
Diagnostic_Methods: CBC, Peripheral blood smear, JAK2/CALR/MPL mutation analysis, Bone marrow biopsy
Treatment_Protocols: Low-dose aspirin, Hydroxyurea (high-risk patients), JAK inhibitors
Related_Conditions: Thrombosis, Progression to myelofibrosis or AML (rare)
